content:
Now that #25180 has been merged, it introduces options on how messages are automatically marked as read to the users. Currently the options are "Always", "Only in conversation views", and "Never". With each options, they come with different unread banners that'll offer clarity to the users on why their messages aren't being marked as read.

Here are the unread banners:
image.pngimage.pngimage.png

One issue with this is that the phrase "Your Zulip app..." isn't used often. Perhaps we can improve the wording on this. What are folks opinions on this?

I'd like us to figure out a rewording that doesn't use the phase "Your Zulip app" -- something like "You have configured Zulip to ..." might be better. We also might want to think about changing the banner color from the warning orange to an "informative notice" blue/green like we use for the "File is uploading" banners.

Hmm, for the color, yellow feels appropriate for the rightmost banner (since something usual is going on for the user there), but I agree that another color might be better for the situation where you've configured a setting.
I think of green as our success notice banner color, which doesn't really fit this situtaion. Is blue just used for file uploads right now?
@Vlad Korobov in case you have feedback here.

Alya Abbott said:

I think of green as our success notice banner color, which doesn't really fit this situtaion. Is blue just used for file uploads right now?

Yeah, I think only file uploads use that color, but conceptually it's our "informative" banner color, and we can probably use it here.
Agree with Tim
Works for me. @Joseph Ho would you be up for updating the color for the "Your Zulip app is configured..." banners to blue?
We can keep thinking about the wording.
Sure!

Wondering how folks feel about this change:
image.png
image.png

The only problem with this change is that the link color is also blue. Thus, there isn't enough contrast between them.
I think we can integrate the color change, and consider #24877 to be the next step for testing a solution to make that link more visible.
“To not mark” is a split infinitive.
Are you saying we should rephrase it as "not to mark"?
Yes (if we’re okay with asking for re-translations at this time).
I think we should rewrite the string to not use "Your Zulip app ...", so yeah we're definitely OK with asking for re-translations.
“You have configured Zulip not to mark...”?
That works for me.
"Vous avez configuré Zulip pour ne pas marquer" gets properly translated by Google (and presumably people) from both the colloquial form and the pedantic form.
#25369
That works for now. If we later change the default, we might not want to claim you did anything :smile:.
I think a version that would be robust to our changing the default (or the org admin doing so via "default user settings for new users") might be worth further fiddling.

Mm, yeah, that's a good point. Now that you mention it, that's why I ended up with the somewhat awkward passive voice wording to begin with. This might be a default user setting configured by the admin, not a setting you personally touched.
Maybe something in the direction of "Your display settings are to only mark messages as read on scroll in conversation views."?

So the other banner would be something like:
"Your display settings are not to mark messages as read on scroll."?

Maybe (with a link somewhere):

Messages will not be automatically marked as read, as configured in your display settings.
Messages will be automatically marked as ready only in conversation views, as configured in your display settings.
And maybe rename the settings option "Mark messages as read on scroll " -> "Automatically mark messages as read"? I think it's been brought up before that "on scroll" is hard to understand.

Joseph Ho said:

So the other banner would be something like:
"Your display settings are not to mark messages as read on scroll."?

I think this is less clear than:
"Your display settings are to not mark messages as read on scroll."

In the former version, it says one thing that the settings are not, but it doesn't say what they are. In the latter, it says what the settings are.

There's nothing wrong with a so-called "split infinitive". Here's the Modern Language Association:
https://style.mla.org/split-infinitives/
and the Britannica editors:
https://www.britannica.com/dictionary/eb/qa/Split-Infinitives
and Merriam-Webster:
https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/split%20infinitive
The main problem with that sentence isn’t whether the infinitive is split, but the mismatch between the plural “settings” and the singular setting to which the infinitive refers.
Thank you @Greg Price for defending colloquial language. People speak the way they speak for a reason.
Sure, agreed. (re the plural/singular mismatch)

@Anders Kaseorg You don't have to be super pedantic about everything. Can you please allow me to not stress about splitting infinitives? Can we say "Direct Messages" instead of "Direct messages" so that normal humans can make the "DM" connection?
I’ll be as pedantic as I please, but I’m not allowing or disallowing you to do anything—I wasn’t even talking to you.
You can also be less arrogant.

Steve Howell said:

Anders Kaseorg You don't have to be super pedantic about everything.

Steve Howell said:

You can also be less arrogant.

Steve Howell These kinds of comments are not appropriate here. We should discuss (and express our different opinions) about specific questions like "Direct message" vs. "Direct Message" and the wording of this banner without negative personal remarks.

Anders Kaseorg said:

The main problem with that sentence isn’t whether the infinitive is split, but the mismatch between the plural “settings” and the singular setting to which the infinitive refers.

Hm, so does "Your display setting..." sound OK, or it weird?

I guess the wordier "Messages will not be automatically marked as read, as configured in your display settings." probably works fine with the plural?
Sure, or maybe the last part can be replaced with a parenthetical “(configure)”.
I've opened up #25379 for the color changes.
@Joseph Ho posted a review with some quick feedback on naming; otherwise looks good.

I was working on #24877 to improve the visibility of links on banners but I found this:
image.png

That's the result of elements not having a dark theme styling and could also be found in other banner such as:
image.png

I decided to copy the stylings from compose banners and match them which results in these:
image.png
image.png

I'm wondering how folks feel about this?
@Joseph Ho is likely the correct thing to do.
Opened #25416 but I want to note that there isn't any hover effect for the "Mark as read" button as I'm not sure what it's hover color should be.

OK, attempting to finalize the banner language, how about something like this?

Messages will not be automatically marked as read. Change setting
Messages will be automatically marked as read only in conversation views. Change setting
The second one doesn't make clear that you're seeing this banner because it's a conversation view.
Maybe "Messages will not be automatically marked as read because this is not a conversation view. Change setting" would work for that.
Mm, yeah. Not super easy to parse, but I'm not sure I have a better alternative.
We could also say "because this is an interleaved view", as an alternative to conversation views -- the /help/ doesn't define "conversation views" either, so it could define both if desired.

I think that "because this is an interleaved view" sounds possibly worse(?) as it's more clear on the what, but I think it raises more questions on "where would the messages be automatically marked as read".

Ok, so the proposal currently on the table is:

Messages will not be automatically marked as read. Change setting
Messages will not be automatically marked as read because this is not a conversation view. Change setting

I think if we don't come up with a better proposal by tomorrow, we can go ahead and implement this change.

How do folks feel about the menu option label?

  • Current: Mark messages as read on scroll
  • Proposed: Automatically mark messages as read

Okay so I've updated #25416 to use the colors suggested in #22524 and here's how it looks now.
Before:
image.png

After:
button hover active
Works for me.
I honestly like the proposed version of the option label much more than the current one. It's much cleaner and sounds nice.

Alya Abbott said:

Ok, so the proposal currently on the table is:

Messages will not be automatically marked as read. Change setting
Messages will not be automatically marked as read because this is not a conversation view. Change setting

I think if we don't come up with a better proposal by tomorrow, we can go ahead and implement this change.

Looks like Anders Kaseorg updated #25369 to match that; I went ahead and merged it; we can always edit further but I think it's quite likely we'll stick with that.

Alya Abbott said:

How do folks feel about the menu option label?

  • Current: Mark messages as read on scroll
  • Proposed: Automatically mark messages as read

I want to bump this up. Should we continue with the change to the proposed text? Currently we've already changed text on the unread banners and they're now using different wording. I feel like the change to the proposed label text would help align them better . Thoughts?
Thanks for the bump! There weren't any concerns expressed and a couple of folks like it, so I think we can go ahead and make the change. Let's update the help center page in the same PR.
(Tim Abbott confirmed offline just now that it looks good to him too.)
Sounds good!
Opened #25481.

#25481 has been merged on Monday which includes the change of the setting option label to "Automatically mark messages as read".
image.png image.pngimage.png

Open to how folks feel about this change!

I just changed this to never, thinking it might only mark messages read when the blue box was moved over them, but apparently that isn't the case. I can understand that 'never' would mean not to mark them as read, but equally the help text for the option appears to point to manually marking as read as 'when the box moves'? Or is that interpretation incorrect?

Since this option doesn't do what I thought, I'll likely go back to the original setting and marking as unread when the web app is over-zealous.

I might reconsider if there was a hotkey to mark a topic as read, which is that GUI-only button on the banner?
(searched in the hotkey menu for 'read' to no avail)

I think your interpretation is incorrect. This setting follows the "Mark messages as read on scroll" setting from Zulip mobile where:
Always - Messages are automatically marked as read as the user scrolls which is the default.
Only in convosation view - Message are only automatically marked as read when the user is in a convosation view (topic, dm, group chat).
Never - Messages are never automatically marked as read and the user will have to manually mark these as read.

In all of these cases, there isn't any differences between scrolling through the feed with the keyboard or the mouse. Really it's just when the reading state should be paused or not.
In that case, the help feels misleading - or else it's since the help page is short, and it's unclear which entry 'manually mark read' (?) points to?

equally the help text for the option appears to point to manually marking as read as 'when the box moves'?

Perhaps changing https://chat.zulip.org/help/marking-messages-as-read -> https://chat.zulip.org/help/marking-messages-as-read#configure-whether-messages-are-automatically-marked-as-read would help?
2 messages were moved from this topic to #design > help page highlighting by Tim Abbott.
I think changing that link would be helpful (though more so if we address the thing I've moved to #design > help page highlighting).

Neil Pilgrim (neiljp) said:

I might reconsider if there was a hotkey to mark a topic as read, which is that GUI-only button on the banner?
(searched in the hotkey menu for 'read' to no avail)

That's a good thought -- we probably will want to add a "mark as read" keyboard shortcut if we want to make this option something that keyboard heavy users will be excited to use.
Was there any consideration to a mark-on-select variant of this feature?

Just to clarify, the "mark as read automatically" behavior in general is to mark as read when (1) scroll through whatever mechanism such that the blue box crosses a message and (2) when the bottom whitespace at the end of the feed appears. So the proposal would be to have an option to only do (1)?

Correct, just (1).

So then there could be:

  • Always => blue box + whitespace visible (everywhere)
  • conversation view => blue box + whitespace visible (only conversations)
  • [new: "blue box" only] => blue box (everywhere)
  • never => neither blue box or white space visible (everywhere)

While I understand the simplicity of selecting from the dropdown, including more of the meaning of each would be clearer, and 'never' feels distinct?
Possibly the meaning could translate better into an interface like the following, with the box deselected making the dropdown inactive:

[x] Mark messages as read when selected, or the end of a view is visible
    |v
    | everywhere
    | in conversation views

That would be without my proposal above.

I think it'd be simpler to just have two settings, "Mark messages as read when scrolling past", and "Mark views as read when reaching the bottom", that each could have everywhere/never/conversation views only.

I don't think I understand the use cases for these settings. Why do we need separate configurations for the blue box vs. reaching bottom? What preferences/usage patterns/etc. would make people want those two to work differently from each other?

The main situation is a keyboard heavy user who might want to explicitly mark things as read should select the they mark as read via blue box in conversation views and disable marking as read via reaching the bottom, and they'd effectively use the down arrow and similar keys as their mark as read keyboard shortcut(s).
I'm not sure an independent setting is actually required for that goal ... but in general every time we've made a setting that squashed together two independent things it's been a mess.

That use case sounds more like an additional checkbox for whether you ever want to mark messages as read when reaching bottom? It doesn't seem connected to which views you automatically mark messages as read in vs. not.
Possibly -- but I could see myself considering "Only in conversation views" for "mark as read on scroll to bottom" but "Always" for "Mark as read when moving the cursor past a message", for example.
I'm not sure I'd prefer that configuration; but I could see myself wanting to try it.
Why?

I'm not sure about the very detailed granularity of settings above, but I can imagine that Tim's preference would resolve issues users have stated with unexpectedly marking messages as read near the end of interleaved views.
great feature. Thank you. Now I want arrow to switch the focus rectangle from last message to Mark as read button, is there a way to do that?
Mm, yeah, that would be handy! Should I go ahead and open an issue for that?

Hmm, yeah, that feels like a good answer for "What should the keyboard shortcut be to mark a conversation as read?" brought up in #design > mark as read shortcut -- just arrow down an extra time and hit Enter.
I also think that such banner shouldn't closable?
Mm, yeah, maybe not. I guess you can still mark a stream or topic as read from the left sidebar, but you'd need to figure that out.
I mean... it could be closable but there is no need in X icon

I think the main thing motivating an x icon is that I can imagine folks finding it a bit bold/distracting. The banner styling we're using for it was designed for a "notice about something that's news to you", e.g. a reaction to something you did in the app... and I think a version that can't be closed but also is a lot more subtle is the direction we should be moving in, at least for the case where you're using one of these settings.

Should we add "automatically" to the text on this banner?

Screen-Shot-2023-05-18-at-2.44.58-PM.png

So it would be:

To preserve your reading state, this view does not automatically mark messages as read.

I think it would be more consistent with similar banners we have (example below), and it's also bit confusing to have a "Mark as read" button next to the current wording.

Screen-Shot-2023-05-18-at-2.48.01-PM.png
I'm not sure how critical is that. But if I mark topic as read from the context menu... the banner is still there. I'm using an option which doesn't mark messages as read automatically
CleanShot-2023-05-19-at-00.42.22.gif

Mm, yeah, not critical, but would be good to fix.

@Joseph Ho would you be up for taking care of both of the points above when you get a chance?

Yeah that's awkward. I remember having a conversation in #issues > remove unread banner with Tim Abbott. We should probably continue on the conversation in that thread since it has a possible solution that'll cleanly remove the unread messages when marking all messages as read.

In #25693, Evy said:

I'm curious if this should actually be an info banner? I don't see much difference between the warning-ness of this banner and the mark-as-read banner.

Where she expressed that the "To preserve your reading state..." banner should be an info banner rather than a warning banner. I wanted to post it here and see what folks think about it. I personally think it may be better to have it as an info banner as well.

Alya Abbott said:

Should we add "automatically" to the text on this banner?
So it would be:
"To preserve your reading state, this view does not automatically mark messages as read."

While we're at it, we should also decide on this.
Yeah I think info banner is probably reasonable -- let's try it and see how it looks.
By the way I use they/them pronouns, not she/her
Thanks for following up on this! Info banner makes more sense to me too
Ahhh sorry about that, I didn't notice. I'll keep that in mind for the future!
I've opened up #25981 a couple days ago to change the banner type.
Just a quick update that #25981 was merged last week, so these banners are now all of the blue/"info" type. Feedback appreciated.
Oh, it's not on chat.zulip.org quite yet; I'll do a deploy later today to fix that.
